Honey Bees are
the only insect that
make food that
humans eat.

Honey is like bee vomit!
The bees bring the nectar
back to the hive and
regurgitate it into the honey cells.
Then they flap their wings
to evaporate the bee-vomit
until it becomes honey!

Honey Bees flap their
wings constantly.
One reason is to keep the hive
at a steady temperature
year round.
They like it to be
92-93 degrees.

Honey Bees can
learn and remember.
No matter how far they
fly, they can always
find their way home.

Honey Bees live in colonies
and they rely on each other.
They are social insects.

A Honey Bee only stings
if it feels threatened.
They die after
only one sting.

Honey Bees have a powerful
sense of smell which they use to
communicate and to find food.
Each hive has it's own
unique odor.

The worker bee lives only
five to six weeks.
They are essential
for the health and
well being for the hive.

A queen can lay up to
3,000 eggs per day
and a hive has
60,000 to 80,000 bees.

Starting in 2006, Honey Bees began to disappear!
1/3 of the bees are now gone.
They simply leave the hive and never return.

This phenomenon is known as

What causes Colony Collapse Disorder?
Scientists think there are a variety of reasons.

Honey Bees are important to humans
because they pollinate 80%
of flowering crops.
That's 1/3 of our diet!

Let's take a look at the role Honey Bees
play in the making of ice cream!

Are you sure
you want to quit?
